entry.title: Setup Blog on GitHub Using Octopress
entry.content:
Brief

I had my github account set up few days ago, and I was excited finding that Github provides a simple way to hosting a blog with just few steps configuration. But the default hosting programe does not flexible enough, so I decided to find something fancy. After few searches on Google, I discovered Octopress. So let’s go rock!

Introduce to Octopress

Octopress is a framework designed by Brandon Mathis for Jekyll, the blog aware static site generator powering Github Pages. To start blogging with Jekyll, you have to write your own HTML templates, CSS, Javascripts and set up your configuration. But with Octopress All of that is already taken care of. Simply clone or fork Octopress, install dependencies and the theme, and you’re set.

Setup Environment

I’m currently working on Windows7-x64. So I only post the env setting for windows x64. I assume the setting up on Linux or MacOS are similar. Octopress needs ruby with development kit and git. So let’s install and configure them one by one.

1. Ruby and Ruby DevKit

Download suitable version of ruby and devkit form Ruby Installer Download Page. Since octopress requires a 1.9.3 above verion of ruby, I suggest choose the latest version. Make sure the version of development kit is corresponding to the version of ruby you installed. As I’m working on a PC running Windows7-x64. I downloaded Ruby 2.0.0-p451(x64) and DevKit-mingw64-64-4.7.2-20130224-1432-sfx.exe. I installed ruby to C:\Ruby200-x64, with Add Ruby executables to your PATH checked. When completed the installation. Press Windows+R, type cmd to open up command prompt. After typed ruby -v, ruby version infomation showed up as follows:

That indicated I had successfully installed Ruby and Ruby executables are added to my PATH. DevKit-mingw64-64-4.7.2-20130224-1432-sfx.exe seemed to be a 7-zip self-extract file. I extracted it to C:\RubyDevKit. Then I opened windows command prompt and changed current directory to C:\RubyDevKit by typing cd C:\RubyDevKit. I generated a conf file named config.yml by typing command ruby dk.rb init. I Edited the conf file with notepad, added following lines to the conf file and saved. Notice that there’s little - at the start of line.

Then I installed it by typing ruby dk.rb install.

After doing all of this, I had my Ruby enviroment set up.

2. Git and Github setup

Octopress also needs git to be functional. I downloaded git for windows and installed with Add git to my PATH. I checked the version of git by following command.

Next thing I did was granting my PC with access permission to my github account. Fisrt I generated ssh key.

Okey, I had my public ssh-key stored in file id_rsa.pub. I opened my github account setting page with my browser and clicked SSH Keys on the left. Then clicked Add SSH Key button, gave the new key a name such like GitHub for bash – Windows7-x64-PC. Then I copied the content of fileb id_rsa.pub to the Key field. Finally, I clicked Add Key to complish the key-adding process. By typing ssh -v git@github.com I checked my SSH-Key settings. I found You've successfully authenticated, but GitHub does not provide shell access. message in the output log, and that indicated I had successfully granted my PC with access permission to my own github account.

Install Octopress

I forked octopress to my own github by clicking fork button on Octopress Github Repositery. Then I got my own copy of octopress with link https://github.com/mygithubaccountname/octopress, thus everything I did to it will follow me everywhere I go. I cloned the repository I just forked to my PC by Github For Windows. I think git bash can do the same work, but I do like a pleasant user interface. Then I opened command prompt and changed directory to octopress and typed the install command as follows: bash $gem install bundler $bundle install $rake install But I ran into an error, error message was : bash rake aborted!You have already activated rake 0.9.6, but your Gemfile requires rake 0.9.2.2. Seems like I my gemfile required a lower version of rake. So I edited the Gemfile. I changed the line gem 'rake', '~> 0.9' to gem 'rake', '~> 0.9.6, and tried rake install again. This time everything went fine. I had octopress installed successfully.

Configure Octopress

I opened _config.yml file with Sublime Text 3 editor and saved it using UTF-8 encoding. Then I did some paper work.

I did not want date string in my post url, so I add this config permalink: /blog/:title/. I went to Ruby installation location and changed directory to C:\Ruby200-x64\lib\ruby\gems\2.0.0\gems\jekyll-0.12.0\lib\jekyll. Opened file convertible.rb , change self.content = File.read(File.join(base, name)) to self.content = File.read(File.join(base, name), :encoding => "utf-8"). This added UTF-8 support.

Write New Post

I started to write this post by typing following command.

And a new file named 2014-04-09-setup-blog-on-github-using-octopress.markdown was generated in source/_posts folder. I edited it with Sublime Text 3 editor.

Preview Post

When done with editing, I typed the following command to preview my new post in browser.

The preview url is http://127.0.0.1:4000. Press Ctrl+C to quite preview process.

Deploy Blog to Github

I was satisfied by the preview, so I decided to do the last step – deploy my blog to github. I created a new repositery on gitbub named scenix007.github.io. Notice that the repo-name is restricted to be something like gitbub_username.gitbub.io to get things work. Then I went to my local octopress directory, and type rake setup_github_pages, then input my github repositery url like:

This url can be found on the home page of your repositery. The last thing, hit rake deploy command to make the final deployment. Github took almost 15 minutes to get my site up for the first time. And that’s it.
